awd_titl_txt: K3 Surfaces, Derived Categories, and Cubic Fourfolds
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry occupies a central place in modern mathematics, interacting with number theory, representation theory, homotopy theory, complex analysis, mathematical physics, and other fields.  The PI studies concrete problems in algebraic geometry using the derived category, which first appeared in the 1960s as a bookkeeping device for homological algebra but which in recent decades has emerged as a fundamental geometric invariant in its own right, and as a conduit of ideas from string theory to algebraic geometry. This project contains a strong component aimed to the training of students at different levels in algebraic geometry.

The research program consists of three related projects.  The first aims to unify a number of examples of "K3 categories," sometimes billed as "non-commutated K3 surfaces," that arise in connection with birational and hyperkaehler geometry, in a common construction.  The second aims to show that a derived Torelli theorem does not hold for Calabi-Yau threefolds, using an invariant called BCOV torsion to distinguish between two spaces with the same Hodge structure.  The third deals with several questions of a more classical flavor about four-dimensional cubic hypersurfaces.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on several kinds of spaces with special and interesting geometry: so-called K3 surfaces, named after Kummer, Kaehler, and Kodaira, and their higher-dimensional cousins called Calabi-Yau and hyperkaehler varieties, the latter sometimes constructed from K3 surfaces and sometimes from four-dimensional hypersufaces defined by cubic equations.  All of these lie within algebraic geometry, an area of pure mathematics, and all involved a balance between explicit geometric examples and abstract theoretical tools, especially derived categories of coherent sheaves.

With the hyperkaehler varieties constructed as moduli spaces of sheaves on K3 surfaces, my student Takahashi and I wrote a paper describing an action of the Lie algebra sl_2 on their derived categories, extending earlier work of Nakajima and of Cautis, Kamnitzer, and Licata, while my student Wray wrote a PhD thesis proving that the universal bundle on the product of the K3 surface and the moduli space, and certain slices of it, are "stable" under good conditions.  With cubic fourfolds, Giovenzana and I wrote a paper describing the the cohomology of an eight-dimensional hyperkaehler constructed from them, which determines when the eight-fold is birational to moduli spaces of sheaves on K3 surfaces, and my student Brooke wrote a paper on a hyperkaehler fourfold constructed from a cubic fourfold containing a plane, which is fibered in Abelian surfaces and has interesting arithmetic.

With Calabi-Yau threefolds, Bragg and I found examples fibered in Abelian surfaces that exhibit unexpected behavior when one works not over the complex numbers but over a field "of positive characteristic," while my postdoc Tighe and I settled a question about the Torelli problem described in the project proposal but finished after the grant ended.  Both of these made heavy use of the computer algebra systems Macaulay2 and Magma.

Elmanto and I wrote a paper on higher algebraic K-theory with finite coefficients and the point at which it becomes the same as topological K-theory, making connections with cohomology and algebraic cycles, analyzing many examples, and proving a new case of the integral Hodge conjecture.

For broader impacts, the grant gave summer support to three PhD students and supported me while I supervised a number of undergraduate theses and research projects, and I made an outreach visit to a high school in Washington state where I spent a day speaking to math and physics students.
